and the Shoshoni were driven out of the country This was before the horse era and the principal weapon was a flint pointed spear The Shoshoni at Blackfoot Idaho visited by the informant s brother a few years ago told him that they have the same tradition The Crows then ranged along Milk river The Blackfoot confederacy drove them southward The Kutenai lived in the mountains west of the divide but visited the plains in early autumn to hunt buffalo returning across the mountains for the winter They were on friendly terms with the Blackfoot tribes Crows Shoshoni and Flatheads which term included the Kalispel were always attacked when found on the prairies The Flatheads crossed the mountains at the head of Marias river or at Waterton lakes or at Crows Nest pass The Cree were fond of living in the woods They were north of Edmonton Winnipeg and Regina also along Red Deer river They hunted buffalo on the prairies near Medicine Hat They were always hostile to the Blackfeet The territory of the Blackfoot confederacy extended north to Battle river east to Medicine Hat southeast to the lower part of Milk river south to Marias river Occasionally these tribes went as far as Yellowstone river but here they had to be very cautious on account of the Crows The Assiniboin were on the prairies in the Winnipeg country and ranged on both sides of the international line The Blackfoot tribes did not frequently encounter them but when they did there was always fighting The Stonies northern Assiniboin had then long been isolated from the parent Assiniboin following a quarrel between two chiefs and these were generally on good terms with the Blackfoot tribes The Sarsi were practically a member of the confederacy The Atsina after their separation from the Blackfoot tribes with whom they associated after quarreling with the Arapaho were always hostile The separation of the Atsina from their close relations with the Blackfoot group occurred in this wise A party of Flathead buffalo hunters was returning from the prairies at the junction of Milk and Yellowstone rivers One of them turned back and ran off a band of Atsina horses In his flight he passed close to a Blackfoot camp Some of his captured horses escaped and mingled with the herd of that camp The next morning a Piegan went to look after his horses and a party of pursuing Atsina rode up They assumed that he was the thief and despite his denial he was shot His name was Many Butterflies He was an old man and a prominent chief His son Eagle Buffalo also was a chief As soon as the latter learned what had happened he organized a party of warriors and pursued the Atsina overtaking them before they reached their camp This was the beginning of the constant warfare between the Atsina and the Blackfoot tribes Raids were frequent Efforts were made to bring about peace but the principal Atsina chief Star Robe obstructed them He was the one who instigated the killing of Many Butterflies The second winter after the original trouble Short Neck whose two sons had been killed at that time feeling very depressed and desiring revenge took his pipe and went from lodge to lodge giving a smoke to various good warriors and asking them to help him So a war party set out following down Milk river Two scouts went ahead One night they found a camp and lay in wait until there was an opportunity to run off two horses On these they returned to their friends with the report that they had found a camp at Bear mountains Immediately they set forward At the camp they waited for daylight and then attacked They routed the Atsina but the latter soon returned to the scene and made a counterattack A good many were killed on both sides The returning warriors blackened their faces with charcoal and when the people at home saw them they knew they had been successful Then Short Neck blackened his face and felt satisfied Encounters between the Blackfoot tribes and the Atsina were deliberately sought so bitter was the feeling whereas fighting with other tribes was usually the result of casual encounter in debatable territory or the unavoidable result of running off horses The expedition sent out by Short Neck occurred in 1858 The informant s father was living and indeed one of his sons participated The following quotations from early observers relate principally to the range population and general habits waters of the South Branch are the Picaneaux to the number of from twelve to fifteen hundred men Next to them on the same water are the Blood Indians of the same nation as the last to the number of about fifty tents or two hundred and fifty men From them downwards extend the Black Feet Indians of the same nation as the last two tribes their numbers may be eight hundred men Next to them and who extend to the confluence of the South and North branch are the Fall or Big bellied Indians Atsina who may amount to about six hundred warriors They the Blackfoot tribes are the people who deal in horses and take them upon war parties toward Mexico 2 The younger Henry gives an extended account of these tribes The Blackfeet Bloods and Piegans may be considered under one grand appellation of Slave Indians 3 The tract of land which they call their own at present begins on a line due S from Fort Vermillion to the South Branch of the Saskatchewan and up that stream to the foot of the Rocky mountains then goes N along the mountains until it strikes the N Branch of the Saskatchewan and down that stream to Vermillion river Painted Feather s band of Blackfeet are the most eastern next to them are the Cold band of Blackfeet near these again are the Bloods and the Piegans or Picaneaux dwell along the foot of the mountains These people in general are remarkably stout tall and well proportioned men The language is the same among the three tribes Their complexion is rather swarthy although they frequently have a fair skin and gray eyes with light hair In dress and manners they nearly correspond with the natives of the Missourie which I have already mentioned in my journal These Slave Indians daub their bodies robes and garments profusely with red earth which appears to be the principal article of their toilet They have another favorite pigment which they procure on their excursions beyond the Rocky mountains of a glossy lead color which is used to daub their faces after red earth has been applied This kind of paint tends to give them a ghastly and savage appearance The elder men allow their hair to grow and twist it in the same manner as the Assiniboines but instead of forming the coil on the crown they wear it on the forehead projecting seven or eight inches in a huge knob smeared with red earth The young men allow theirs to flow loose and lank about their necks taking great care to keep it smooth about the face they also wear a lock hanging down over the forehead to the tip of the nose there cut square and kept smooth and flat as if to hide the nose They wear no breech clouts and are quite careless about that part of the body Their dress consists of a leather shirt trimmed with human hair and quill work and leggings of the same shoes are of I8o THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN and all are friends again About 20 years ago the Piegans amounted to only I50 tents so much had smallpox reduced that once numerous tribe but their numbers are now increasing fast They are arrant beggars whose haughty souls cannot brook the idea of refusal They resent our supplying the Columbia Indians with arms and ammunition Still they boast of never having murdered one of us or stolen any of our horses The country which the Piegans call their own and which they have been known to inhabit since their first intercourse with traders on the Saskatchewan is as I have already observed along the foot of the Rocky mountains on Bow river and even as far S as the Missouri The buffalo regulates their movements over this vast extent of prairie throughout the year as they must keep near these animals to obtain food In summer they are obliged to assemble in large camps of from 100 to 200 tents the better to defend themselves from enemies In winter when there is not so much danger they disperse in small camps of 10 to 20 tents make pounds for buffalo and hunt wolves and kits There are 30 to 40 tents who seldom resort to the plains either in summer or winter unless scarcity of animals or some other circumstance obliges them to join their countrymen This small band generally inhabit the thick woody country along the foot of the mountains where they kill a few beavers and being industrious they are of course better provided for than those Piegans who dwell in the plains The latter despise labor and will not kill a beaver or any other fur animal to enable them to purchase an ax or other European utensil though beaver are numerous in every stream throughout their country They frankly avow that war women liquor and horses are all their delight Many families are still destitute of either a kettle or an ax The women who are mere slaves have much difficulty in collecting firewood Those who have no axes fasten together the ends of two long poles which two women then hook over dry limbs of large trees and thus break them off They also use lines for the same purpose a woman throws a line seven or eight fathoms long over a dry limb and jerks it until the limb breaks off Others again set fire to the roots of large trees which having burned down the branches supply a good stock of fuel The trunk is seldom attacked by those who have axes as chopping blisters their hands Kettles are very scarce particularly among those who dwell in the plains They generally roast their meat on a wooden spit before the fire or broil it on coals The paunch of the buffalo or other animals serves to contain water They are not nice or clean in their cooking They have no particular hour for meals all day meat of some kind is on the fire Their culinary utensils are few and very rough Wooden dishes of different dimensions are made of aspen or poplar knots spoons are formed of the same material or more commonly of buffalo s or ram s horn Some of the latter are very large holding about two quarts and answer as both dish and spoon They are seldom entirely out of food for they keep a stock of dried provisions on hand for emergencies as buffalo sometimes disappear and it may be several days before they can get a fresh supply When they are reduced to dried provisions they call it starving So much do these people abhor work that to avoid the trouble of making proper pounds they seek some precipice along the bank of the river to which they extend their ranks and drive the buffalo headlong over it If not killed or entirely disabled from the fall the animals are generally so much bruised as to be easily dispatched with the bow and arrow But this method sometimes proves dangerous for if the leading buffalo on coming to the edge of the precipice is not entirely exhausted she may refuse to make the leap suddenly turn about and break through the ranks followed by the whole herd carrying before them everything which offers to obstruct their progress No effort of man suffices to arrest a herd in full career after the cow that leads them and thus lives are sometimes lost as the natives standing near the precipice to form the ranks and see the buffalo tumble down have no time to get out of the way The ordinary dress of these people is plain and simple like that of all other Meadow Indians plain leather shoes leather leggings reaching up to the hip and a robe over all constitutes their usual summer dress though occasionally they wear an open leather shirt which reaches down to the thigh Their winter dress differs little from that of the summer their shoes are then made of buffalo hide dressed in the hair and sometimes a leather shirt and a strip of buffalo or wolf skin is tied around the head They never wear mittens I have frequently seen them come in to our houses after a I0 or 15 days march over the plains in the depth of winter with the thermometer 30 to 40 degrees below zero dressed with only shoes leggings and a robe nothing else to screen them from the cold War seems to be the Piegans sole delight their discourse always turns upon that subject one war party no sooner arrives than another sets off Horses are the principal plunder

away like sheep but within a few years they have acquired firearms and become formidable The severe defeat the Piegans sustained last summer did not discourage them from renewed enterprises of the same nature They are always the aggressors there never has an instance been known of a native coming to war from the W side of the mountains The Crows are the only nation that sometimes venture northward in search of the Slaves The Snakes are a miserable defenseless nation who never venture abroad The Piegans call them old women whom they can kill with sticks and stones They take great delight in relating their adventures in war and are so vivid in rehearsing every detail of the fray that they seem to be fighting the battle over again A Piegan takes as much pleasure in the particulars of the excursion in which he engaged as a Saulteur does in relating a grand drinking match how many nights they were drunk and how many kegs of liquor they consumed In smoking there is more ceremony among the Piegans than I observed in any other tribe Some of them will not smoke while there is an old pair of shoes hanging up in the tent some of them must rest the pipe upon a piece of meat others upon a buffalo s tongue Some will smoke only their own pipe which they themselves must light others again must have somebody to light it for them and then it must be lighted by flame only no live coal must touch it nor must the coal be blown into a blaze No person must pass between the lighted pipe and the fire particularly when in a tent The first whiff from the pipe is blown toward the earth while the stem is pointed up the second whiff is blown up and the stem is pointed down or sometimes to the rising sun the midday and setting sun may also receive their share of attention Those ceremonies being over the pipe is handed around as usual I once observed a fellow who would not smoke in our houses but having been given a bit of tobacco he took his own pipe went out of doors and made a hole in the ground in which to rest the bowl while he smoked Such proceedings are tedious and often troublesome to us in our business when a large band comes in as the whole performance is slow and serious They are superstitious to the utmost in various other things some must have a person to cut their meat into small pieces ready to eat others always eat and drink out of one particular bowl or dish which they carry for that purpose some never taste wild fowl or fish some never eat particular kinds of flesh or allow their victuals to be cooked in a kettle used for such viands The greatest oath a Slave can possibly utter is that the earth and the sun hear him speak this they consider sacred and inviolable in all their transactions 1 According to Black Eyes all the Piegan Bloods and Blackfeet participated in the treaty with the United States in i855 but they remained nomadic roving on both sides of the international line In I872 the boundary treaty of I846 was ratified and the Indians were made to understand that there was to be no more crossing Thus there came to be two distinct bands of Piegan In winter the tribes lived in many bands scattered along the river bottoms The Piegan were usually along Old Man river in Alberta and on Marias river in Montana sometimes both bands being together The Bloods were usually on Belly river the Blackfeet on Bow river The country however was not divided among the tribes of this group any might summer or winter wherever it chose In summer the bands coalesced into much larger units and roamed the buffalo plains In midsummer each tribe congregated in some previously selected place for the Sun dance and the activities of the societies Early in the fall they proceeded north to Edmonton or south to Fort Benton to trade In travelling the chief selected and announced the place for each night s camp MARRIAGE Overtures were begun either by a father who desired a son in law or by the young man himself If a youth thus approached by a father was acquiescent his family proceeded to make clothing On the appointed day all the girl s possessions were loaded on a travois along with a tipi cover and were taken to the dwelling place of the young man s father where the tipi was set up About two days later the young man s family loaded a horse with clothing and other gifts for the girl s family The tipi in which the young people lived was usually a ceremonially painted one if the families were of good rank The value of the goods given to the girl s people was usually a little greater than that of the gifts received from them Sex relations were rather loose A husband discovering his wife in adultery could kill her 1 Coues II 523 530 542 722 728 731

I82 THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN or mutilate her without interference from her relatives If the woman s father heard of the difficulty before harm was done he would ask the chiefs to restrain the wronged husband If they persuaded him to listen to reason the father would promise him a younger daughter for his second wife This was a frequent solution of the trouble The wife of an adulterous husband could protest to his father who would remonstrate with his erring son If that accomplished nothing she would report the matter to her own father who might advise her to return to her own family and if she did so the goods given with her were demanded back TRIBAL ORGANIZATION There were no clans The tribe consisted of a large number of bands clustering about an equal number of minor chiefs Within the band most of the people except the women who had married into it were related They were thus practically patriarchal groups Usually a wife was taken from another band and in most cases she joined the band of her husband However if a man considered that he would have a better opportunity of advancement with the aid of his father in law he could join the band of his wife without incurring ridicule Great respect was shown to a woman or a man married into a band The appellations of these groups were usually of the nature of nicknames To call them local bands is misleading for they travelled and camped together the members of a given band in close proximity it is true but not connected with any particular locality The patriarchal conception of the bands is confirmed by the method of succession to the chiefship A chief recognizing that his end was near would summon the men of his band and there name his successor and deliver a speech urging obedience to him If he died without naming his successor the members of the band agreed on the best man among his relatives Preference was shown for his brothers then for his nephews and his sons Good sense means and hospitality were the qualities desired in a chief Often the chief had a younger brother whom he groomed for the office and in such cases this individual was named by the people even if the chief s death was so sudden as to prevent him from publicly naming his choice A chief attaining such an advanced age that his capacity for leadership was impaired delegated his office to a successor The retiring chief thenceforth was relieved of all duties except making the public announcements for his successor A chief always had a number of young self attached retainers living in his household ready to do his bidding guarding his horses hunting carrying messages These were the worthy sons of poor men who otherwise would have had a meagre chance of marrying well On account of the rank of their protector they became desirable as sons in law and in return for their long service the chief himself supplied the necessary purchase price of the bride When such a young man received the girl s dowry he gave a horse or two back to his chief A duty of the chief was to give to very poor people a few hides to trade in at the post These hides he accumulated in large number by the efforts of his retainers and of other young men whom he supplied with good hunting horses in return for which he received all the hides taken the hunters themselves retaining the meat SOCIETIES There was a group of societies partly military and partly religious in character A society is called ihkuntkaafi plural ihkunukaafiiiks Following are the names of the societies as they formerly existed I Kak6ylks Pigeons 6 Maist6hpatakiiks Raven Carriers2 2 Soyisksissiiks Mosquitoes 7 Imitaiiks Dogs 3 Mafilks from mafitski a fearless man Braves 8 Sinopaiiks Kit foxes 4 Kanaftomitaiiks Reckless Dogs 1 9 Iinakiiks Soldiers 5 Issoynks Tails 10 Stimikiiks Bulls Membership in the societies depended on age the youngest men joining Pigeons and proceeding upward through the series by selling their membership and paraphernalia to their juniors and buying those of their seniors Those who joined Pigeons were usually of an age suitable for induction into practice of warfare The rule was that a man spend four years in each society but the change could be made in three years When the informant was a Pigeon there were about forty members but he has seen as many as fifty to sixty in tribes with a larger 1 strouding in which raven feathers were thrust

rites including transfer of memberships and public dancing only in the tribal encampment just before the Sun dance All the societies are said to have originated in dreams Thus the origin of the Bulls and the Tails is accounted for as follows A woman went out to arrange the wind deflectors of the tipi and while she was thus engaged somebody seized her from behind and carried her away It was a Buffalo He took her to the Buffalo village There were two society lodges the Bull and the Tail The Buffalo were just like humans They removed their coats and went about like people The woman suffered no hardship Her captor who made her his wife showed her all the secrets and the dress of these societies and told her to instruct her people She remained in the Buffalo village a year and then returned and introduced the societies The principals in these two societies had buffalo head dresses others feather war bonnets which they wore also in battle The purpose of the societies was to promote warlike power Women had the status of lay members of the societies in which their husbands were active They took no part in the dancing but assisted in the singing Unmarried women were sometimes asked to join the Pigeons taking the place of retiring Pigeon women who dropped out of the system until they married members of elder groups In such cases the Pigeon men made up the price exist among the Bloods and are the principal society there The original name of this group refers to a head dress of the leader which has a buffalo horn on each side and one in front The nickname Kit foxes refers to the skin which formed a part of the costume 1 Some of the Piegan belong to the Horn Society of the Bloods and the society is active among the Blackfeet The latter assert that this was an ancient institution among them recently revived at the suggestion of the Bloods When an Indian appears before the civil authorities he is asked if he believes in the Horns and if he answers affirmatively he is permitted to take the oath upon the tenets of the society instead of upon the Bible Even non members do this The sun is the deity addressed in Horn prayers heard by non members In spite of the general belief in the Horn religion the membership is limited The informant saw a recent meeting which about twenty attended The lodge of any society is made by uniting the covers of two or three tipis over an oval frame But the Horns have a very large circular tipi In I873 when the informant was a Pigeon aged twenty he was living for a time among the Montana Piegan On his return home he learned that his society had been sold in toto to the Bloods Not having participated in this transfer he still retains his membership and the young men are asking him to revive the society He would be able to do this by having young men buy memberships from the surviving relatives of deceased members those who died before I873 The society system broke down about the time mentioned because of the greatly depleted population after an epidemic of smallpox The present activities of the Braves and the Reckless Dogs are practically limited to meeting and singing their songs at the time of the Sun dance There are now numerous societies such as High Hat Eagle Feather Cree Horse Racers Bronco Busters which hold dances for amusement They have nothing in common with the former system being merely groups of dancers The Grass dance is in a somewhat different class It was obtained from the Sioux among whom it is said to have originated in the dream of a man who slept near a flock of prairie chickens and dreamed that they were dancing The prairie chicken leader instructed him in the dance The performers have feathers dangling from their shields SACRED BUNDLES AND CEREMONIAL PLANTING of I84 THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN rattles Its custodian is called y6hkimo mopistan has water bundle Custodianship is acquired by purchase and those who participate in the ceremony of opening the bundle and dancing with the skins form a pseudo society Members of this group are usually perhaps always those who have pledged themselves to buy one of the skins after recovering from sickness Should the buyer of a skin ask the custodian of a bundle for permission to take his new possession home the latter would give him the entire bundle thus transferring his custodianship Of course the new guardian would have to pay the usual price Since an adult member of the tribe could not possibly be ignorant of the conditions governing technical ownership of the skins it appears that such an instance must arise from a deliberate plan to acquire custodianship of the bundle Each member after the opening of the bundle dances with the skin he has purchased while all sing the song pertaining to that skin The ceremony begins early in the morning and dancing continues at intervals through the day ceasing only from time to time when some one gives a sharp rap on the tipi poles The singers sit in a row each on a folded rawhide on which he strikes his rawhide rattle The custodian and his wife dance while holding up the dibbles that are kept under the bights of the rope wrapping of the bundle The principal Beaver bundle was shown the writer in a tent at a haying camp It lay in the place of honor on a pile of folded rawhides It was wrapped in a tanned buffalo skin colored red and was securely wound with plaited rawhide rope Under the turns of the rope were two hardwood dibbles each having the incised outline of a beaver on its flat side The handle ends were ornamented with beads With the sticks were two long pipes separately wrapped in red flannel The ceremony of planting tobacco is held in great awe The following account apparently half myth and half legend purports to explain the origin of Beaver bundles and ritualistic tobacco planting Apikifti White Finger camped with his wife at one end of a lake near Chief mountain Ninnaastakuyi He hunted on foot and when he returned his wife was not there He spent two days searching for her He thought I will search no more But I will wait four days and if she does not come back I will go On the fourth day at sunrise he heard someone singing in a low tone The sound came from the south He did not look out The sound passed to the west to the north to the east It came into his tipi There were three men and the missing woman The man who had taken the woman away had a bundle of beaver skins He laid it at the back of the lodge One said My companion gives you these skins The Beaver men instructed White Finger in the songs that pertained to the bundle The woman had already learned them in her sojourn among the Beavers After the Beaver men had gone White Finger and his wife came back northward to their people carrying the bundle on a dog drawn travois When they showed the bundle of skins the people said This man has something wonderful At his tipi it was necessary to be very quiet and especially to avoid any knocking sounds as one would do in the vicinity of a beaver colony The skins and the man and the woman were painted red When a pipe was offered to them the head was presented first not the stem and they rested the bowl on the ground when they smoked They used red paint and blue paint A Blackfoot friend of this man went to the trading post at Edmonton and obtained some tobacco He returned and sent a messenger to White Finger offering him tobacco for half of the beaver skins Some time later the two tribes met in a large camp The Blackfoot visited White Finger and said Did you receive the message I sent you offering tobacco for half of your skins I have also six dogs and I will give you three of them His friend agreed and divided the bundle and took half of the skins to the Blackfoot s lodge in the same way that the Beaver had brought the bundle to him He gave him instruction in the songs and taboos The Blackfoot asked Are you going to plant tobacco next year If you are wait for me We are going apart now and I will collect all the meat back fat and berries I can In the spring the Blackfoot sent word to White Finger to wait for him so that they might plant together As he journeyed he met a man who told him that the Piegan had already planted his tobacco The news depressed him He turned back and camped alone with his own band on Red Deer river He went up on a small hill and sat there very downcast He was facing north He noticed some snowbirds flitting about him They sang Sleep where our children are Have pity on them They have power He slept and when he woke he looked in a clump of buckbrush and found the nest of the snowbirds They told him to plant tobacco beside the nest He returned to his camp and ordered his men to prepare the ground

serviceberries with the seed and planted They moved away From time to time they made a stick in the likeness of a man clothing it with small moccasins and leggings The sticks would come to life and quickly go to the garden and return with news of its condition They departed from that region to the buffalo country and after hunting all summer and storing quantities of meat and fat in the fall they started back Nearing the planted ground they sent two men ahead to observe its condition and return to a certain place where the band would camp The scouts reported that the plants were tall and thick Then they were glad They moved forward to camp near the garden four nights before harvesting the crop On the second night a brother of this chief crept out and stole some plants In his sleep the chief knew it The next morning he called out Whoever took tobacco from the garden must bring it back He told his wife that he suspected his brother She asked the younger man but he denied it Nevertheless the chief was certain of his guilt The next evening when he knew that the tobacco would not be brought to him he sang for rain That night it rained heavily with lizards The reptiles crept everywhere looking for the stolen tobacco While the people slept they crept up to smell their breath One of them discovered that the breath of the chief s brother smelled of tobacco smoke The lizard tried to enter the man s mouth but he woke seized it and pulled it from his lips Immediately he began to vomit tobacco smoke The chief heard the sound and came running He said You were the first to deny that you stole my tobacco But I forgive you I hope you will have no bad luck from this The next day they gathered the tobacco With the first leaves plucked they filled a pipe and they prayed for good luck before harvesting the rest The tobacco seed came from the Beaver and the Snowbirds helped by showing how to mix it with deer droppings and berries The Blackfoot man afterward learned that the Piegan White Finger had had no crop at all Even today the Blackfeet have much better crops than the Piegan MEDICINE PIPES Among the northern Piegan are now four medicine pipes ninamskahkuiniman ninamskan a man painted from head to foot that is a shaman ahkuiniman pipe Formerly there were many but some have been sold to the Blackfeet and the Bloods The material is stone naturally white but blackened in the smoke of buckbrush The stems are apparently maple and the bore is made with a heated wire by four men who first recite their war records If they tell a straight story they will succeed in boring a straight hole The stems are painted and wound with weasel skin Eagle tail feathers ornamented with dyed porcupine quills dangle from the mouth end The Piegan explain the origin of the pipes by the following myth Three girls caught in a thunderstorm took refuge under a tree The eldest addressed Thunder Do not harm us If you have a son I will marry him The following summer she was walking outside the camp A young man met her and said I have come for you My father told me you promised to marry me She accompanied him and after a time he said Close your eyes Soon she found herself in a strange place She was in the sky She became homesick and her husband promised to take her home Thunder gave her a pipe wrapped in a skin Her husband brought her back to the earth and returned to his father In the spring at the first occurrence of thunder a dance is held and one of the pipes is removed from its wrappings and on each succeeding day another of the pipes is similarly used In memory of the origin of these pipes a woman of the household of the custodian is always the one to open the bundle which she does when a certain song is reached by the custodian A person desperately ill may pledge himself to take a medicine pipe if he recovers As soon as he is able to walk he goes to the tipi where the pipe is kept and is painted by the custodian who then brushes the pipe over his body Later completely recovered he takes possession of the bundle by giving a dance and a feast and paying a goodly price in horses skins and blankets Eight to ten horses or the equivalent are customarily paid If a custodian retains possession four years and then wishes to recover his investment he one evening during the Sun dance calls five or six former custodians to his lodge and they agree upon some man possessing sufficient means to take the pipe They summon a good warrior and send him to spy upon the tipi of the man so selected He creeps upon the tipi just as if he were a war scout VOL XVIII 24

I86 THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN and having found that the man is sleeping pulls up a tipi peg or a door pin and brings it back as proof that he has been close to the enemy He recites the account of four of his exploits against an enemy and concludes As my words are true you will find the enemy asleep and will have no trouble The woman opens the pipe bundle and just before dawn the custodians without the woman creep upon the enemy camp bearing the pipe They seize the man at the same time shaking the pipe and so sounding the small bells with which it is decorated By this sound the man immediately becomes aware of the situation They pass the pipe over his body and so it becomes incumbent upon him to take it They wrap it in a blanket and return to their own tipi accompanied by the man and his wife There the owner gives new clothing to his successor and his wife does likewise to her successor By this time it is daylight and the people become aware of what is going on Some immediately join two tipis into a long structure and a dance and feast follow in the course of which the pipe is delivered to the new custodian The retiring guardian dances with the pipe and former custodians dance with the stuffed owl the rattle and the wooden or gun barrel whistle that form a part of the sacred bundle The horses and goods that are to be paid for the pipe are brought to the tipi by the relatives of the new owner all of whom join in helping purchase the bundle For three days the new owner must not rise from his bed before his predecessor arrives to sing and pray with him The same rule applies to his partaking of food Before mounting a horse for the first time he must have the former custodian paint the animal and help him mount The pipe bundle hangs from a tipi pole in the rear of the lodge at the head of the custodian s sleeping place In good weather his wife makes incense with the dry leaves of creeping cedar and either hangs the bundle outside above the door or lays it across a tripod which she leans against the tipi and fastens by a thong so that the wind may not overturn it which would portend very bad luck At sunset she brings it inside burns incense and hangs it in the usual place Before moving camp the bundle with its tripod is set up in the open with the forward leg of the tripod pointing in the direction of the line of march The custodian leads the march and his wife carries the bundle on her travois His lodge is always pitched inside the arc of the circle occupied by his band Red paint is much in evidence in connection with medicine pipes The travois or saddle on which it is carried the tripod on which it rests the tipi poles from which it hangs are covered with paint The horse is daubed here and there The whip is painted The custodian and I88 THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN singing The in side sang while the others watched In starting a game a player of each side hid his markers and a pointer on each side made his guess If both lost or both won the proceeding was repeated If only one lost the winner took one of the ten tally sticks and held the deal The game was frequently played between societies or between tribes with great excitement and high stakes After the first preliminary round a member of the in side held both markers and gave or pretended to give one or both to a companion During the singing the two concealed them in their hands both in one hand or in any possible arrangement The pointer on the other side then indicated by an appropriate gesture where he thought the markers were to be found The forefinger indicated the long one the thumb the short one When one marker was correctly indicated it was killed and the in side thereafter had only one marker to work with until it also was killed For each incorrect indication the in side took a tally stick and when both markers had been disposed of the other side took the deal Losses by a side having a store of tally sticks were paid by replacing the necessary number in the common store There were sixteen possible arrangements of the markers which perhaps was the reason the aged informant was uncertain as to most of the gestures SOCIETIES Blackfoot informants do not agree as to either the number or the sequence of the societies The partial decay of the system many years ago is a credible explanation of this fact Bear Bull named the following I party went afoot against the Cree In the battle an old man was shot in the leg and his fleeing companions abandoned him For many days he lay unconscious He saw a flock of ravens flying above him When he woke he heard singing in a bush Raven spoke to him You are going to be safe You will not die Then it addressed the other Ravens All come together We will dance The old man opened his eyes and saw a large number of Ravens in a circle The Raven chief said You see how we are doing When you go home do likewise He watched what they did They were like men They sang and danced The chief told him that when anyone was sick he should promise to join the society and he would be made well When the old man arrived home he secured the necessary feathers made the costumes and staffs and organized Raven Carrier society The two leaders had long staffs one of which was decorated with eagle tail feathers the other with strands of scalps The third leader had a buffalo rattle decorated with eagle feathers He was the one who led the dancers in and out He had a raven skin on his head All the other members had short staffs with raven feathers hanging from them and held them pointed upward and forward while they danced The three leaders were always old men The Black Soldiers originated in the dream of a Blackfoot man Each member wore a wolf skin head band with two feathers upright at each side and wolf skin anklets and wristlets The body and limbs were painted red and there was a black band across the forehead and the chin On the cheeks were two black lines representing the wolf s canine teeth He bore a long spear tipped staff painted red and having wolf skin strips hanging from it The leader had in addition a wolf skin draped from his shoulders The Black Soldiers danced in a circular crowd moving slowly in a circle stepping high uttering wolf cries at the end of their songs the leader outside the throng and moving in the opposite direction They shook their spears in a minatory manner If any member was absent they danced four times making motions with the spears in the direction of his tipi and then rushed upon it and cut up everything belonging to him tipi clothing and whatever was there They were camp police in the large encampments If they warned the people that nobody leave camp they pursued anyone who disobeyed and capturing him cut up his clothing and then returned to destroy his tipi A thoughtful provision was that if the pursued being surrounded dismounted and drew a line on the ground about himself none could enter this symbolic entrenchment except a man who in war had performed a similar feat If such a one were present and came to the attack the besieged had only to make his blanket into a bundle and toss it to the enemy The Black Soldiers then withdrew without molesting him and without even harming the blanket Or the pursued could take refuge in the water because wolves which the Black Soldiers represented abhor water and none could go after him except one who had killed an enemy in the water a rather remote chance If he ran into a tipi only one who had entered a tipi to kill an enemy or capture booty could follow him and he could only take the blanket and destroy it This also very rarely happened Old men invariably say with great positiveness that the Soldiers would cut up everything tipi clothing medicine robe anything Closely questioned however two old men one of whom was formerly a member the other of whom frequently saw the Black Soldiers in action were able to recall only a single occasion when anything of this kind happened A man who had once entered an enemy lodge followed a fugitive into a tipi brought out his blanket and tossed it to his companions who cut it up In no other way did they molest the culprit On another occasion they saw the Black Soldiers fling a man into the water because he had failed to attend a meeting of the society Both informants have frequently seen the Black Soldiers destroy the tipi and the personal clothing of negligent members In view of the various means provided for the escape of non members and the frequency of punishment meted out to members it appears that these latter occasions were deliberately arranged for the purpose of impressing the populace The informants however deny that such was the case Asked to explain how any member could be such a fool as to risk the loss of so much valuable property difficult to replace they reply that sometimes a man did not want to dance and deliberately absented himself Probably if such was the case these episodes were the result of

I9o THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN personal pique An Indian whose feelings have been injured whose pride has been assaulted takes little account of consequences This society became defunct soon after the advent of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police An inspector of that body visited the reserve and ordered that the Black Soldiers no longer have the right of punishment They continued to hold their annual dance but soon gave up even that about the year I890 The Soldier society was much like the Black Soldiers but the men were more severe even striking their victims with clubs and axes The important emblems of the society contained in a bundle included a pointed yellow stick ornamet with yellow calf hoofs and a calftail and a long pipe as well as a bow and arrows In pursuing a culprit they carried the sticks and struck at him if unable to lay hands on him The leader and an assistant had charge of the pipe and another man and assistant had the bow and arrows They bore these in the dance Each member had a punitive stick of the kind described but only that of the leader was kept in the bundle These sticks they carried in the dance holding them before themselves moving them up and down A man desiring to join the Soldiers in order to aid in the recovery of himself or a relative might buy the bundle from the leader or technical possession of any part of it from one of his assistants or the stick emblem from any of the ordinary members A large price was required for purchasing the position of leader In the summer camp the people were very cautious about absenting themselves on days when the Soldier society was to dance They brought up their horses early in the morning and kept them near the tipis so that should the Soldiers begin their dance unexpectedly they would not be caught away from camp looking for their animals and receive punishment Sometimes a man well provided with property or the son of a wealthy man would vow that if he recovered from sickness he would let the Soldiers destroy his personal clothing The following summer when the Soldiers started to dance he would dress in his very best raiment put his finest blanket on his horse and stand near the dancers After the fourth dance the Soldiers aware of his vow would rush upon him tear his garments from him and utterly destroy them even to a blanket worth twenty horses Having finished with him they would run about wildly threatening with their sticks cutting clothing of the men here and there The two informants old men strove to give the impression that the Soldiers practically ruined the clothing of their victims and declined to make a direct answer to the question whether these occasions were not largely sham They admitted they never had seen anyone really abused by the Soldiers Twice they saw the Soldiers take hold of a man and hustle him a bit swing him from the ground tear at his shirt without really damaging it They once saw two young men who had made the vow set upon by the Soldiers who tore their blankets down the middle and ripped their shirts without taking them from their bodies They used no knives It thus appears that the drastic treatment said to have been meted out by the Soldiers was mainly hypothetical The same means of escape were provided for fugitives from the Soldiers as in the case of the Black Soldiers The Ugly Horn society was dreamed by a Blackfoot The two leaders wore fringed leggings a fringed ill fitting garment like a woman s dress and fringed moccasins all of smoke blackened tipi cover Joined to the dress with thongs was a large loose fitting hood fringed at the bottom provided with white circular holes for eyes and mouth and having two large ear like flaps at the sides These last were the ugly horns from which the society took its name Each leader had a staff wrapped with tipi cover leather Along one side of the staff were numerous rattlers of buffalo hoof Other members wore loin cloth moccasins and a head band of black tipicover or of any skin they preferred The body was painted yellow or any other desired color In the head band was a feather at each side In their annual summer dance the leaders went about inside the circle of the tipis frightening children into good behavior The society became obsolete about a generation ago The Kit fox society has not existed since the smallpox epidemic of I841 when all the members except one died and he took his medicine to the Horn society This explains the assertion of the Piegan informant quoted on page I83 that the Kit fox society is the equivalent of the Horn society of the Bloods and the Blackfeet The Mafsiiks society was founded by a young man who is said to have lived among the Bears Two members personate bears having a bear skin sash and bear skin at the sides of the head representing ears Two black lines downward from the eyes stand for the canine teeth

severally vowed that if they recover they will dance with some certain skin at the monthly openings of the bundle which occur from November up to the planting season As soon as he is able each such individual visits the custodian and informs him of the vow and the custodian is expected to pray frequently for him When the members assemble the custodian opens the bundle and sings the songs with their assistance and each member of the group dances with the skin mentioned in his vow The entire procedure re enacts the myth of the origin of the Beaver bundle as outlined above The members participate thus from year to year and not merely in the year following the vow The ceremony lasts all day and about sunset the custodian feeds the members and they go home This is done each succeeding month until the leaves start that is the month of May Each new member pays the custodian for technical possession of a skin and this act is called picking up the skin In May the tribe pitches a temporary camp near the tobacco garden A double lodge is erected and the members of the Tobacco society are called in about dusk The entire population attends for it is considered very unlucky to be absent from this important ceremony The custodian s wife opens the bundle takes out the otter skin and ties it to a pole which she leans against the outer tipi wall so that the skin hangs down from the peak like a pennant Ten members then dance each holding a stick the crooked root end of which is encased in a small moccasin These sticks are not kept from year to year but are prepared anew each season to be left standing like guards overlooking the tobacco garden Just before dawn they feast Outside is a crowd of young men dressed in their finery each bearing a pole to which near the pointed end is attached some article such as a feather head dress or a medicine object At the words Come wet your sticks the young men one by one thrust the pointed ends of their poles through the doorway and the cooks transfix pieces of meat on them The youths withdraw the poles and feast In the morning they sleep and later in the day the entire membership walk to the place where the tobacco is to be planted and many spectators follow The custodian of the bundle goes ahead walking slowly and singing At intervals of about twenty five yards he stops the others do the same and he prays for a good crop Arriving at the chosen spot he puts down the beaver skin and a beaver skin head dress He places some sticks on the ground and prays that they may have good luck and cause no grass fire He touches a match to a bit of punk and with this lights a bunch of dry grass and starts the fire The others stand about the space to check the flames When the plot is burned off they go back to the lodge and sleep Tobaccoseed chokecherries service berries dung of buffalo elk and deer in this sequence are then placed in a rawhide bag with water and allowed to soak The night is spent in singing and dancing and mixing the seed Early in the morning they march to the garden and clear the ground of sticks The bearer of the bag of seed and fertilizer sets it down the custodian of the Beaver bundle takes it and prays to the man who first acquired the sacred bundle from Beaver Old Man imploring good luck with the seed While singing and praying he makes a number of holes with a dibble and having finished the song he bids the others proceed in like manner Each individual plants a strip of the plot and sets an identifying stake at each end of his row Finally the custodian bids the children run over the plot One who unfortunately falls while doing this will not live long it is thought They return to break camp and move about halfway back to the permanent camp Three days they remain there then all except the Tobacco members pack up and return to the main camp After the others have gone the members assemble in the Tobacco lodge Outside are two young men with fast horses sticks one in advance of the others This one represents the custodian of the bundle and the others are his fellow members They stand there as guards of the crop On each stick are a diminutive moccasin a bead necklace a tobacco bag a small pipe After the return of the two youths the members pack up and return to their homes In August the society meets to sing and dance and they send a young man to the garden to report on its condition The members gather on a hill whence they can observe this scout If he walks back and forth they know that all is well and go down to look at the crop Any

I96 THE NORTH AMERICAN INDIAN member whose portion of the crop is not flourishing is much depressed for this portends sickness and perhaps death in his family l They sing and pray in preparation for gathering the crop The seed and some of the leaves are placed in the Beaver bundle Most of the tobacco is smoked in the ceremonies of the bundle and only when hard pressed does a member use this ceremonial tobacco for ordinary smoking When the society assembles each member brings a portion of his tobacco and gives it to the leader for use in the rites MEDICINE PIPES There are six pipe bundles not including one recently sold to a collector Anyone having serious illness in the family may vow that if the sick person recovers he will take one of these pipes This is supposed to be very effective in causing recovery If the expected result comes to pass he goes to the owner of the bundle he had in mind tells of his vow and takes the bundle away after appropriate prayers and agreement on the price to be paid In raising the necessary sum in horses and other property he has the assistance of numerous relatives In one instance of recent occurrence sixty horses besides clothing and money were paid for a pipe Having purchased a pipe bundle a man holds it until some other person buys it as the result of a pledge He is merely the temporary custodian and does not perform as a shaman SHAMANS A shaman is called assokinaki Shamanistic power is obtained by keeping a vigil in a solitary place such as a high cut bank If the seeker is lucky some animal will appear to him in a dream and show him what roots and herbs to use and what songs to sing When called to treat a sick person a shaman makes incense of sweetgrass holds his hands in the smoke and places them here and there on the patient s body until he finds where the sickness is He may then blow on that part through a long hollow stick like a pipe stem and so expel the sickness or he may place his mouth on the part and suck it out In the latter case he spits out on a bit of rag or a chip a small black wormlike object which he throws into the fire Of course he sings his songs Many individuals know the use of certain vegetal products for certain maladies but they are not therefore shamans Wolf Collar gave the following account of his shamanistic experiences When I was seventeen a strange thing happened to me About noon Thunder struck me in the teeth and on the left arm and side I lay there until sunset Thunder gave me a tipi and a shield 2 She told me to fear nothing that I would become an old man She appeared as a great bird and suddenly became a woman She gave me her husband That is she promised that he also would help Wolf Collar Four years later in a vision while I slept the male Thunder gave me another painted tipi This I afterward gave to another Blackfoot and the firstone to my brother who gave it to a Montana Piegan When I painted the first tipi all the people came to see it They believed in me It was strange that while I was singing the songs there was lightning and it stopped when I finished my songs When I painted the second tipi and put it up and sang there came wind and rain but no lightning Every spring I go to Duck Chief and sing for him the songs that go with the shield This generally brings a storm Possession of this shield and of the tipis has given good luck but no healing power Each owner of these things has become a prosperous chief With the first tipi were three songs with the shield two with the second tipi three The songs of the first tipi are 3 1 Recently a white employee of the agency while rounding up cattle saw the tobacco garden and in his ignorance of custom reported to the Indians that their tobacco was doing well A short time thereafter his horse stumbled in a badger burrow threw him and killed him This the Indians regard as vindication of their belief that intruding upon the Tobacco ceremony is fatal 2 The shield made by Wolf Collar in fulfillment of his vision is now in the possession of Duck Chief having been sold to him with its medicine It is of buffalo hide and around the edge are tail feathers of a yellowhammer and several hanks of human hair and crow feathers at intervals Across the lower segment is a blue cloud on which is perched a young Thunderbird with lightning flashing from its eves 3 Before singing Wolf Collar uttered a prayer to our father that is God the informant being now a member of the Christian church He sang with an incredibly nasal whine

to pray Four times I did all this and then prayed a long time Suddenly the blanket twitched Spring Chief sat up He was perspiring Water ran down his face and his body He looked around He called me Wolf Collar I am well again I laughed I took more of my water put some of the earth in it and gave him to drink It was winter and I said Spring Chief do not fear snow and cold Get up we will go home I threw open the door He walked out dressed as he was When his father in law saw him he met him at the door and embraced him and all the others did the same I said Since you are well again in seven years time you will be completely well After seven years he began to grow larger and now he weighs about three hundred pounds Wolf Collar is called upon to cure people struck by lightning On such occasions he sings the Thunderbird songs and rubs a mixture of yellow paint and wet clay on the chest of the patient He has been summoned to treat four such persons and saved all of them Once a man and his wife were struck The man was badly burned and Wolf Collar made no effort to cure him The woman was thrown a little distance from the man but was not burned and her he saved

pages.http://memory.loc.gov/award/iencurt/cp18: The North American Indian List of Large Plates Supplementing Volume Eighteen 616 A Chipewyan tipi among the aspens The Chipewyan are one of several Athapascan groups occupying the territory between the Hudson bay and the Rocky mountains from about the fifty seventh parallel to the Arctic circle Much of this area is barren but the streams that feed and drain the innumerable lakes are bordered by thick groves of the slender white boles of aspens whose pleasant glades are favored by camps of fishermen and berrypickers The Chipewyan dwelling formerly made of the skins of caribou on which animal these people principally depended for food clothing and shelter was one of the few points in which their culture resembled that of the plains Indians Their distinctive garment was a leather or fur coat with skirts cut to a point before and behind a feature to which the appellation Wichipwayaniwuk they pointed fur people the Cree original of Chipewyan alluded 617 Titishu kghitluhl Deer Running The Sarsi are an Athapascan tribe which prior to the nineteenth century came out of the far north crossed the Saskatchewan and becoming affiliated with the Algonquian confederacy of the Bloods Blackfeet and Piegan became typical plainsmen following the buffalo engaging in horse stealing raids and in general adopting the religious practices of their allies Old Sarsi as the subject of this plate is colloquially known was ninety eight years of age when the photograph was made in 1925 In spite of his years he was still agile and keen 618 Tsaaassi mis salla Crow with Necklace Sarsi The name colloquially rendered as Crow Collar refers to a neck ornament of crow feathers 619 Muwu His Tooth Sarsi The childhood nickname His Tooth completely supplanted the formally bestowed Star Child 620 A Sarsi camp The scene is a riverside grove near Okotoks Alberta where a band of Sarsi were awaiting clement weather to begin the prosaic labor of shocking wheat for one of their Caucasian neighbors 621 A Cree canoe on Lac Les Isles The Western Woods Cree Bush Cree Swampy Cree or Maskegon as they are variously known are scattered in numerous bands through the wooded country north of the prairies between Hudson bay and the Peace river drainage Other members of this large family inhabit the plains in Manitoba Saskatchewan and Alberta and the country from Lake Winnipeg to Lakes Mistassini and Nitchequon in the Province of Quebec They are members of the great Algonquian stock and are closely related to the Chippewa Lac les Isles locally known as Big Island lake is in west central Saskatchewan near the Alberta border The canoe is a well made craft of birch bark 622 A Cree girl The garment here illustrated is a robe of twined strips of rabbit fur 623 Moose hunter Cree Cree hunters are masters of their art of imitating by means of a birch bark trumpet the call of a moose of either sex and thus luring within gunshot an animal seeking a mate during the rutting season 624 Cree tipis 625 Moss for the baby bags Cree In moist localities of the northern bush country the ground is thickly carpeted with Sphagnum The moss is dried on racks and is used as an absorbent in the tightly laced bags of infants 626 A Cree Of variously widely differing types noted among the Cree at Lac les Iles the subject of this plate and that of the following one were perhaps best representative of Cree physiognomy 627 A Cree woman 628 A Cree camp at Lac les Isles A family group consisting of two middle aged women a young mother and several children camped at the lake while the rest of the band were haying in a swampy meadow some miles inland They engaged in fishing with a gill net and in gathering blueberries In point of sanitation their tipi and their cooking methods left much to be desired 629 Chief Hector Assiniboin The Assiniboin are an offshoot of the Yanktonai Sioux from whom they separated prior to 1640 The southern branch has long been confined on a reservation in Montana the northern is resident in Alberta The latter is divided into two bands which formerly ranged respectively north and south of Bow river from the Rocky mountains out upon the prairies Hector is chief of the southern band of the Canadian branch known locally as Bear s Paw band 630 Assiniboin hunter 631 Kindling fire Assiniboin The fire drill is unknown to the oldest Assiniboin traditionists but striking fire from flint was apparently as aboriginal method 632 Assiniboin mother and child 633 Painted tipi Assiniboin A tipi painted with figurines commemorative of a dream experienced by its owner is a venerated object Its occupants enjoy good fortune and there is no difficulty in finding a purchaser when after a few years the owner according to custom decides to dispose of it 634 Placating the spirit of a slain eagle Assiniboin For their feathers which were used in many ways as ornaments and as fetishes eagles were caught by a hunter concealed in a brush covered pit A rather elaborate ceremony took place over the bodies of the slain birds for the purpose of placating the eagle spirits The Sarsi custom is described at some length in Volume XVIII pages 95 99 635 Agichide Assiniboin 636 Blackfoot country Since the beginning of the historical period the Blackfeet have ranged the prairies along Bow river while their allies the Bloods and Piegan were respectively on Belly and Old Man rivers In the earliest times of which their traditionists have knowledge the three tribes were respectively on Saskatchewan Red Deer and Bow rivers 637 A Blackfoot travois The travois is still used for transporting bundles of ceremonial objects Before and sometimes even long after the acquisition of horses travoix were drawn by dogs 638 Medicine headdress Blackfoot By long usage the term medicine in the sense of supernatural has become firmly fixed in the literature of American Indians and especially the plains tribes A head dress of the sort here depicted consists of some part of the body sometimes the entire skin of the creature that appeared as a spirit in a dream of the wearer and instructed him how to have its help especially in war 639 Oksoyapiw Blackfoot 640 Bear Bull Blackfoot The plate illustrates an ancient Blackfoot method of arranging the hair 641 Calf Child Blackfoot 642 Blackfoot tipis 643 Fleshing a hide Blackfoot The implement for removing flesh and fat from hides is a long bone with a beveled scraping edge The thong attached to the upper end and passing about the woman s wrist is for the purpose of giving additional leverage 644 Bow River Blackfoot 645 Lodge of the Horn Society Blood The Horn society is the custodian of a cult about which the natives are loath to give details It stands apart from the system of age societies which though partly religious in character were more concerned with warfare and the preservation of order in camp Numerous taboos apply to the conduct of Horn members and there are sexual rites in which the wife of a novice and his sponsor participate 646 Sacred bags of the Horn Society Blood 647 Makoyepuk Wolf child Blood 648 Apio mita White Dog Blood
